Let me explain a bit more.

A few years ago someone posted on Puzzling SE the “birthday‐strokes” puzzle. The idea was that if you write your birth date in Roman numerals (for example “I/III/XII”) and then count – not the number of pen–lifts but rather the “endpoints” or strokes used when drawing the letters in an optimal way (so that whenever two strokes meet at a point, that endpoint is counted only once), you get a surprising number. In fact, if you do it for your birth month you’ll find that January comes out as 1 stroke, February as 3, March as 7, April as 8, May as 21, June as 49, July as 76, August as 224, September as 467, October as 514, November as 1155 and December as 2683.

That is exactly the sequence you mentioned. (Note that different people have come up with slightly different numbers depending on exactly how one “counts” endpoints and whether one allows certain kinds of joins; but this version is the canonical one.)

So in short: The puzzle behind the sequence was “How many strokes does it take to write your birthday?”—or more precisely, how many strokes (when drawn optimally without double‐counting intersections) are needed for writing the Roman numeral representation of each month.
